definition: Zhang Shizhao (1881-1973), revolutionary journalist in Shanghai, then established writer

sentences.english: Zhang Shizhao was a famous statesman and political critic in modern Chinese history.
sentences.chinese: 章士钊是我国近现代史上著名的政治活动家和政论家。

sentences.english: Chapter four talked about the evaluate of Zhang Shizhao's constitution thoughts.
sentences.chinese: 第四章是对《民立报》时期章士钊宪政思想的评价。

definition: Hu Shi (1891-1962), original proponent of writing in colloquial Chinese 白話文|白话文[bai2 hua4 wen2]
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
Chen Duxiu (1879-1942), co-founder of the Chinese Communist Party in 1921
Cai Yuanpei (1868-1940), liberal educationalist, studied in Germany, president of Peking University 1917-19, minister of education for Guomindang
Tang Shaoyi (1862-1939), politician and diplomat

Zhou Zuoren (1885-1967), brother of Lu Xun 魯迅|鲁迅, academic in Japanese and Greek studies, briefly imprisoned after the war as Japanese collaborator, persecuted and died of unknown causes during the Cultural Revolution
Song Jiaoren (1882-1913), politician of the revolutionary party involved in the 1911 Xinhai revolution, murdered in Shanghai in 1913
Li Dazhao (1889-1927), early Chinese Marxist and founding member of the communist party
Wu Yuzhang (1878-1966), writer, educator and communist politician
Liang Shuming (1893-1988), modern philosopher and teacher in the neo-Confucian tradition
Zhou Enlai (1898-1976), Chinese communist leader, prime minister 1949-1976
Wang Ching-wei (1883-1944), left-wing Guomingdang politician, subsequently Japanese collaborator
Dong Biwu (1886-1975), one of the founders of the Chinese communist party
Duan Qirui (1864-1936), commander of Beiyang Army under Yuan Shikai, then politician and powerful warlord
Hu Egong (1884-1951), Chinese revolutionary and politician
Li Zongren (1891-1969), a leader of Guangxi warlord faction
